reply_text:
mjensen415:
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
I would like the community to come together and arrange for me and my dog and possibly my girlfriend to be airlifted immediately to Pitcairn Island.
Thank you for the kind offer.
More seriously, I’d really like Fiverr to maybe go with
@eoinfinnegan
’s earlier suggestion of Fiverr relaxing St. Levels and maybe putting some UI tweaks in place to make sellers’ lives easier.
I’ve been bombed bya client repeatedly ordering in bulk from my single article gig with 1-day delivery, despite me asking him numerous times to message me before placing bulk orders. I’ve finally lost it and just canceled his last order. However, my stats will likely be ruined soon anyway.
The thing is, this wouldn’t happen if we had a feature to limit how many of a certain gig package a single buyer can buy at a time.
Another thing that would make life easier is a 24-hour or 48-hour auto-accept feature for disputes. I got bombed yesterday with lots of people who aren’t replying to extension requests, likely because it is the weekend and they are doing what normies do and are taking time out until Monday.
And would it really be so hard to darken and increase the font size of the fonts in messages, order requirements, and custom offers? - Or let sellers customize this?

reply_text:
Hi everyone! I come from Italy. As you may have already heard, here the situation is truly tragic, especially in Northern Italy. We’ve been in quarantine for 13 days, all non-essential services are closed, and the military and police officers monitor the cities. Many have lost their jobs and self-employed workers are the ones who are suffering a severe blow, economically speaking. Fortunately, I am doing fine. The company I work for allows smart-working and when I don’t work, I have online lessons and dedicate myself to freelancing ( well, and Netflix too). I’ve noticed that several other companies are demanding for people to work remotely. I imagine that in this tragic scenario the world of work gets adapted to the circumstances and I think this is positive for those who now find it difficult to raise some money.
Either way, I hope you are all fine. Wherever you come from, try to stay safe!

one of daughters friends has it. To say its bad is an understatement and this is (a formerly) healthy 20 something. Now its a waiting game to see if anyone here has it. No one in the country is allowed out without a signed paper saying what you are going out for and fines have gone up from 38€ to 1000€ now. if you get caught outside without good reason on more than one occasion you are in serious trouble. No one is now supposed to go more than 1km from the house on foot for any reason at all. if you go shopping or to a medical appointment you have to have a signed paper saying why, when, and time you left the house.
Also… Someone went into a shop here wearing a full face gas mask… my daughter was in the shop and no one could understand what the guy was asking for as his face was covered. the people in the shop told him to take it off because they could not understand what he was saying. An argument and a fight ensued with the customer and the people in the shop landing blows on each other and ended with the customer being kicked out. Happy days

lenasemenkova:
This is getting ridiculous if I’m honest.
On my island, we have had no cases but 1 that was sent to the mainland. The only way to get here is by ferry. All businesses are closed and already people are losing their jobs and can’t pay their bills. It would be easy to prohibit passengers on the ferry and just use the service for goods. This way, life here could continue as something like normal and small businesses would at least stand a chance.
Instead, tourists can get a 10,000 euro fine for not answering the door when a policeman calls to see if they are obeying by quarantine rules. (This means they press buzzers on apartment main entrances that usually don’t work, and guess what time they call?) Businesses can also get a 3,000 fine for opening and at least one has already been fined for trying to do something productive and having staff on-site doing paintwork and maintenance.
It is all madness.
And if you thought Coronavirus was bad, wait for rat flu!
Mail Online – 24 Mar 20
Man who died on bus in China tests positive for virus RATS spread
The victim died on a vehicle in Shandong as he made his way to work and was found to be suffering from hantavirus, which infected rats spread through bites, droppings, urine and saliva.
Then you have that minor problem that is when economies nosedive, public health goes through the floor. Infant mortality rates go up, life expectancy shortens, violent crime goes up, the rate of people choosing to end it all skyrockets, rates of malnutrition go up, disease spreads more easily as a result, homelessness rates skyrocket…
This isn’t just getting ridiculous, it’s dangerous, and the aftermath of this is going to be catastrophic. .

reply_text:
I wonder what life will be like a year from now, or two years from now. We have no real leadership here. (edit: I’m referring to our country, not fiverr.) Nothing is being done at all aside from a handful of scientists in various places studying this. It’s crazy people can’t get tested. We can’t do tele-doctor visits. Not enough masks available for healthcare workers who have to wear two masks, two sets of gloves which they remove the top layer for each patient, etc.
I can’t imagine what our pitiful little local emergency waiting room must be like, parents with screaming babies waiting for hours, homeless people, all sick and coughing, overworked understaffed nurses. Hope I don’t have to find out, in person.
A small ray of hope:
They found the virus doesn’t like hot humid weather, over 63 degrees f. It slows it down.
They also found it does not mutate due to the way it’s put together, unlike the flu, so any vaccine will likely be permanent.
Best hope: a year from now a good vaccine will be available to anyone. And the drug that shows so much promise is widely available to anyone who needs it.
Try your hardest to keep from getting it in the meantime. Do whatever it takes.

I think almost every person thinks of scenarios that are not likely to happen. Me too…
But as a human, I know my genes will do whatever it takes to survive.
That’s why I wear mask, wash hands end spend as much as possible time at home, where I feel safe at the moment.
I try to think of positives that could happen in future, like people’s changed mindset, cleaner water, cleaner air, singing birds, animals re-born, and so on. It makes me feel better than catastrophic future.
We will see later. Stay safe!

reply_text: Our Ministry of Health commissioned a bunch of ads and infographics explaining to people how not to get the virus in a fun visual way. One of the tips was to avoid wild animals at all costs. But “wild” got lost in translation because the translator was bad at their job. The designer was even more of a genius because they illustrated this tip with a golden retriever instead of a boar or a bat. That triggered a wave of panicked citizens bringing their dogs to the shelters, throwing them out to the streets and occasionally putting them down. Be good at your job, people. Wash your hands and think of the puppies.

reply_text:
In a week’s time, there has been more than 330 people diagnosed with COVID-19 and 3 Arkansas residents have died from the disease. We have yet to see a huge number of cases here but, according to our mayor, he doesn’t trust the numbers. He feels the number is much more than four in our county. We’ve been told that the hospitals have the test but don’t want to use them unless they absolutely have no choice.
In fact, from what I’m hearing, the hospitals are turning people away and not testing those even with outward symptoms of this disease. They just tell them to quarantine themselves and wait for 14 days unless they get worse.
I’m trying to avoid the crowds as much as possible. It was 80+ degrees here today, and I would have walked our local park, but got the word that large groups of people were in the park with their kids. No thank you!
Stay well everyone!

Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 44” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 35”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text: Honestly, I’m so confused. I was supposed to have my entrance exams next month, that got cancelled - and it seems like it’ll stay that way for at least 2 months. Now I’m stuck in quarantine without anything urgent to do besides the remote COVID-19 projects for an NGO. My Fiverr impressions and everything are at an all-time low because I had to suspend everything for the exam prep, so that’s a real bummer. And let’s not get started on the supply shortages… On the bright side, I finally have time to watch movies or finish something like a book or a game.

reply_text: Here in New Zealand we have 300 cases but only 8 in hospital and one in ICU. No deaths. Nearly all our cases are people coming home from overseas. We are in total lockdown for 4 weeks. All non-essential businesses are closed. You can only leave home to buy food or medical supplies. Or you can go for a walk near your house. My Fiverr has got busy - I have that sort of gig! Everybody has stocked up on food so the supermarkets have been under pressure.

All in all, I am hopeful that things will get better. Let’s keep hope alive.

I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 44” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 35”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text:
hello everyone
hope you guys doing well. Stay safe

I’m in Malaysia my country are currently in MCO (Movement Control Order).
So I made / cook my own food, playing PS4 and doing orders on fiverr.
Basically that’s my life before covid, so it’s not so big impact to my life as a freelancer , gamer and home cook.
Only what impact is most shop close, only supermarket is allowed but have a limited operate time.
After dark bascially you can’t buy anything, also limited to 1 person go out of the house to get food.
Stay home, Stay safe.
Think about those nurse / doctor / police at the frontline.

Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 44” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 35”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!

reply_text:
So I work with theaters a lot (now it’s obviously slowing down due to the virus because no one can have shows). But I got an order from one of them today. I asked if they were sure they wanted to proceed given the situation because wouldn’t want to charge people for something that will get cancelled 100%.
They said: “All the shows are being hosted online-everyone does their part via webcam from their homes, everything has changed and we are making it work!”
And it just made me happy to see how people change their process and adapt to the hardships. If there is a silver lining in all of this, it’s how creative and inspiring the human spirit really is.

reply_text:
We all need to adapt to not leaving our homes, probably for a very long time. I can’t see this getting better until a vaccine is developed and widely distributed to everyone, which will be at least a year from now.
I hope everyone here is prepared to stay inside that long. Going any place where there are people puts us at risk. The more people now who are not going out, the sooner our health care systems can find ways to deal with all the patients they have, and the fewer of us will get the virus.
I have food delivered to my home. I only touch the bags with rubber gloves on and I wash all of it. I leave the bags of canned foods without touching them for three days. It can take that long for the virus to die when it’s on bags or other surfaces.
There may come a time when I can no longer get food delivered and I’m sure most people here still need to go out to get food. Please wear a mask or cloth over your nose and mouth when you go out.
We are actually experiencing nature adjusting and balancing out our population to protect the earth, the air and lower pollution.

I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 44” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 35”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text: Stay healthy, Stay safe

reply_text:
I caught my dad in a store yesterday (my parents live nearby). He takes all the necessary precautions but he’s 82 and we agreed that I’ll be buying whatever groceries they need and leave them on their doorstep.
He loves fresh bread with his coffee in the morning and who knows how long he’s been sneaking out. Mom says it gives him purpose and we shouldn’t get in the way of him hunting baguettes. I’m horrified and amused at the same time.

reply_text:
I’m in one of the most affected states in the USA (NJ) where we have nearly 50,000 cases already. We’re simply not leaving the house at all. Grocery delivery has shut down everywhere around here, and stores aren’t offering pickup services either. We have people in delicate health in the household. So, we’re living on canned and boxed foods that go through a rigorous self-quarantine and decontamination of their own once they hit our porch. It’s crazy, and maybe excessive, but taking no chances.
Hope everyone’s being safe and staying sane out there. A good time to take up some stress relief habits and watch comedies or read light-hearted books.

Never did I expect COVID to change life as we know it this drastically. Nearly everyone I know has been let go from their jobs. I was promptly sent to work from home then blindingly let go a week later.

Stay safe and indoors everyone!

Hi everyone. If you’re like me, you’ve been getting these “What are we doing” emails from companies about COVID-19. And… that’s great. Thanks for letting me know random company I bought that one thing from 5 years ago.
I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 44” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 35”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!

Sorry to hear of all that! What a nightmare.
We have no working plumbing currently in our ancient house and I’m afraid to let in anyone to fix it since our area is a very high covid area and I don’t want to be around any strangers.
Yesterday we had a complete blackout for a while. Between no plumbing and no lights or electricity it was surreal. At least in a cave we could build a fire and use the outside “restroom”.
I found myself yelling out the front door to the neighbors to find out what was happening with the electricity. We aren’t supposed to go outside at all here. I felt like a trapped animal.
Lena I hope that they are at least working at putting out that fire! You sound like you are in a bad situation there.

reply_text:
Many states here in the U.S. are slowly opening their economies - my state included. To say I’m nervous about how this will all play out is an understatement. As much as I want to get back into the gym or lift weights in the local park, another part of me is saying, this is going to get worse before it gets better.
Last night, instead of attending a concert in Memphis to see Motionless in White, I was at home. The concert was postponed (understandable) and who knows if the concert will even happen. The bright spot of the whole thing is that my school will remain shut down for the rest of the academic year. Now, I do need to go in once a week to get things done such as auditing for next year and payments.
As it stands now, my job is being terminated due to restructuring. I was actually called to ask if I wanted another position in the school as a parapro. While it’s not what I want all the way around, I know I can do the job and will do it as I do anything else in my life. I await the final decision from the board to see if they will make the approval. So, we’ll see!
Thankfully, the Fiverr work has increased, which may be due in part to finding my best gig on page one again with the culmination of an ad I ran.
In the grand scheme of things, I’m just playing the wait and see game and doing work when it comes in.
Stay safe and healthy Fiverr friends!

Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 44” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 35”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text: hope u all doing good, stay safe guys…

reply_text:
QUARANTINE RESULTS REPORT
Since I do reports all the time at work I find it natural to make a report on what I did during quarantine since this is the last Q-day in my country (Croatia). Starting tomorrow business should be slowly returning to normal.
So:
I published 2 new books
I wrote 3 new books and prepared drafts for 12 more
I wrote 5 e-books for students struggling to learn online since schools are closed
I started Fiverr seller account and earned 92 USD
I designed furniture for my backyard and build it together with my crafty neighbor
I repurposed frame of the old trampoline into the gym area
I planted some flowers for the first time in my life
I draw a big “NO SMOKING” sign in my backyard
I started a YouTube channel and helped a kid who was being harassed by others on the live stream
And
I cleaned and organized my office (this lasted for one day and now it is back to random mess)
I discovered there is nothing wrong with my car battery, for some reason car wants to start only if the shift gear is in a certain position
I gain 10 pounds (and then I decided to make gym outside :D)
I actually planted seeds of watermelon next to flowers.
END OF REPORT
Marina no smoking
1600×1200 231 KB

Thank you for the Mexico part. I wish. Then I would know Spanish, my dream language.
I feel sorry for my old self. I had this backyard for 39 years and my day was wake up, go to university, do lectures for 8 hours, then do e-learning for 6 hours, and go to sleep, tomorrow, repeat. Never break, never rest, and the worst part is - nothing, I have nothing from 14 years of that, I worked to buy food and pay bills, the moment I save some money the prices go 30% up. Over and over. All the years of life wasted. I never wanted to invest in the apartment and backyard since it is rented, not mine. I finally got to my senses I need to enjoy in today.

I want to ask how YOU are doing and if there’s anything we as a community can do to help support you during this strange time around the world.
Personally, I’m in the SF Bay Area and we’re on FULL “shelter in place 44” orders. I’m working from home now with three kids (all under 6) so “work time” has gotten a lot crazier (only so many times I can hear my daughter sing “LET IT GOOOOO 35”).
Even if there is nothing that the community can do to help (resources, questions, shared experience), I’d love to hear how your work habits have changed in the last few weeks!
reply_text:
misscrystal:
If you can simply stay home and not come into contact with anyone you can learn to live a hermit’s life and work on being healthy, and improving your gigs. Of course there is always a need at some time to venture outside, or do errands that involve people contact.
Even if you live the Hermit life, you aren’t safe. I got diagnosed with Corona yesterday even though I haven’t left home in weeks. And it absolutely sucks.

Yep, luckily they are mild. I had a fever and a dry cough that weren’t going away so I called a doctor and he was pretty much certain it’s Covid.
Unfortunately, my mom caught it too and it’s hitting her a bit harder. So just be careful. If you think someone has it in your family then get them tested and quarantine them unless you want it to spread.

reply_text:
I also want to point out for anyone who reads this that there are what they call “super spreaders” which are people without any symptoms who have it and spread it around easily to everyone they come into any sort of contact with.
One such person with no symptoms gave it to 32 people.
I was talking to someone I know who says he “doesn’t believe in wearing a mask” yet he it out running around as if it’s not even in existence and has a wife and daughter. It’s one thing to not care about your own health but this is not just about that. It’s about anyone around you that you might infect.

reply_text:
Nah, after the protests, the next pressing crisis will be food shortages, economic Armageddon and, lots of civil unrest.
You have the entire Western world having just willingly closed shop and stayed home for several weeks, only to have lockdowns be proven completely pointless by mass protests undoing any benefit. That is going to upset a lot of people and there is no more money in the kitty to keep paying people’s bills.
I’m pretty sure that in a couple of months, people will be more concerned about catching something for dinner than they will be Covid-19.
On the upside, though. all them, protesters are getting lots of vitamin D.

reply_text:
So, you didn’t take a test?
My older sister, who lives in France, is in a hospital there since several weeks. Doctors thought that was COVID19 due a chronic cough she has, but the bad news was that her breast cancer was returned after 2 years, and now she is starting chemo therapy again in the next weeks.
COVID19 is not so dangerous as cancer. I understand deaths, but the damage of cancer is increasing every day.

reply_text:
ldnarquitectura:
My older sister, who lives in France, is in a hospital there since several weeks
I’m sorry for your sisters situation. However, she might be lucky if France is still treating oncology patients. In Malta and lots of other countries, most cancer screening and treatment is pretty much on hold at the moment. I have a friend with lung cancer who hasn’t been to the hospital in weeks.
ldnarquitectura:
COVID19 is not so dangerous as cancer.
More people have died in building accidents on Malta this year than they have of COVID. However, the constriction industry is the only industry that has been allowed to continue operating as normal throughout the pandemic. Apparently, the cost to the economy would be to great if they ceased operations.
Then you have the suicide rate in the U.S. In some states, they have already recorded more suicides this year than during the entirety on 2019. Sadly, most people aren’t interested in looking at the bigger picture.
I hope your sister recovers and that you can get to see her soon.

thread_name: Q: How does the COVID-19 pandemic impact Rotary’s fight to end polio?
thread_text:
A: In our work to end polio, the program sees the devastating impact that communicable diseases have. With this in mind, we are fully committed to supporting national health systems by engaging our expertise and assets to help mitigate and contain the COVID-19 pandemic, alongside continuing concerted efforts to eradicate polio.
Using the vast infrastructure developed to identify the poliovirus and deliver vaccination campaigns, the polio eradication program is pitching in to protect the vulnerable from COVID-19, especially in polio-endemic countries. From Pakistan to Nigeria, the program is drawing on years of experience fighting outbreaks to support governments as they respond to the new virus

thread_name: Since COVID-19 started I’m getting few jobs from the Spanish industry
thread_text:
Hi, how are you?, long time without posting.
I wanted to ask you about your experience since the coronavirus outbreak. I work with Spanish SEO and orders were drastically reduced, also impressions and clicks. I want to know if the Spanish industry was specially harmed or all marketing people worldwide are facing the same.
Thank you, kind regards.
reply_text:
I can’t comment on the Spanish CEO category, because that isn’t a service category that I am familiar with. However, I can say with certainty that there is a drastically increased level of competition on Fiverr, as a result of the global pandemic. More sellers, means existing sellers tend to see lower metrics from the search results. Perhaps there are too many people trying to sell services for your keywords, and your services aren’t being seen as much.
It’s also worth noting that, people just might not be searching for your services as much. The world is changing – even moreso because of Covid. Perhaps there isn’t as much demand for your services now, compared to in the past.
Perhaps this might be a good time to start marketing and promoting your own services too, instead of relying on only the Fiverr search system to provide all your orders.

thread_name: Blessed by Fiverr in Covid-19 times
thread_text:
When I opened my Fiverr account last year, I had no clue that I would be greatly helped by this platform. I opened my account with curiosity and with the idea to explore. I had my graphics business well set in local market that time and I was doing good.
Slowly and steadily my account was developed on Fiverr and I was giving my time and energy on Fiverr but still my main work and especially revenue was getting generated in local market work.
But then Covid pandemic broke and in India, we have been to longest lock-down. Suddenly there was fear in the market. People around in our area started to consider graphics as the luxury thing and it was not considered essential, so I stopped receiving work from the local market. It was the time when starvation was knocking my door along with the frightening health situation around. Thankfully to Fiverr, I could keep getting my living on the platform. Now, I have started to focus more and more on Fiverr (gave Fiverr tests, added gigs,etc)
I have also decided that Fiverr will be my top priority even after the situation is normalized (though I don’t know when that will happen). I don’t think that my any words will be able to express my gratitude to the platform and to the buyers of my service. Truly obliged.
reply_text: Stay blessed. Stay with fiverr

thread_name: Isolation stress, can’t buy masks or sanitizer either!
frequent_posters: misscrystal, coerdelion, honeyhiphop, lenasemenkova, mariashtelle1, jonbaas, luzhan, arty182925, vasilikit152, vickiespencer, yarasin, saqibhussain516, md_cbd
thread_text:
hey, I have been having to buy groceries for my whole family as they are in isolation due to coming back from overseas, in Australia anyone returning must self isolate for 14 days. It’s stressful because the grocery store stopped doing deliveries as they couldn’t cope with the demand. At the same time you can’t buy masks or hand sanitizer or rubbing alcohol ANYWHERE! I am just praying for everyone who may be going through something like this, or anything related to COVID-19.
STAY BLESSED, POSITIVE AND SAFE!
reply_text:
honeyhiphop:
hand sanitizer or rubbing alcohol ANYWHERE
I am still surprised that people hoarding hand sanitizers but stores are still full of soaps.
Soaps are more effective than Rubbing alcohol. So it’s the same effective to wash your hands after going out, just don’t touch your face during your outings.
honeyhiphop:
At the same time you can’t buy masks
You don’t need it if you are healthy, they are useful in this situation only to protect from spreading the virus if you are sick.

thread_name: Isolation stress, can’t buy masks or sanitizer either!
frequent_posters: misscrystal, coerdelion, honeyhiphop, lenasemenkova, mariashtelle1, jonbaas, luzhan, arty182925, vasilikit152, vickiespencer, yarasin, saqibhussain516, md_cbd

reply_text:
honeyhiphop:
At the same time you can’t buy masks or hand sanitizer or rubbing alcohol ANYWHERE!
@mariashtelle1
is correct… most stores may be out of liquid hand sanitizers, but I’ve been seeing plenty of bar soaps. Those are just as good as liquid hand soap. Heck, dish soap should work too – I wash my hands in our kitchen sink with dish soap all the time.
The point is to wash your hands with soap and water. Soap comes in many formats.
If you can’t find medical face masks, use a bandana or a scarf. The point is to stop YOURSELF from potentially spreading the virus. Medical professionals have been saying that, if necessary, bandanas and scarfs are better than nothing.
Don’t fall into the “you’ve gotta have only this” hype. A little creativity and common sense will help keep us all safe during these challenging times.

There’s nothing wrong with “the normal ones”, if that’s what is available. Soap and water. That’s the key. It doesn’t have to come from a package that says “kills 99% of all germs”.

reply_text:
Hand sanitizer is antibacterial, rather than antiviral. You’re better washing with soap.
Vinegar and lemon juice are antibacterial. Add Tea Tree essential oil, oregano, thyme and even lavender - all of those are antibacterial, antifungal and antiviral.
You can make your own masks- there are plenty of tutorials on youtube for those with or without sewing machines. It’s easy … but a bit fiddly.
Take a breath, folks - this is going to be with us for some time. Constant stress is bad for the immune system, so breath, do yoga (or whatever) … and be open to solutions, not looking for problems …

reply_text:
mariashtelle1:

Shhhhhhh.
Jokes aside, I don’t think I’ve ever seen a bottle of sanitizer in a store since it all started. They just vanished from existence.
honeyhiphop:
It’s stressful because the grocery store stopped doing deliveries as they couldn’t cope with the demand.
Yeah, same here. I did some panic shopping on Saturday, asked the delivery guy how they were doing. He assured me things were under control, people’s shopping habits haven’t changed that much and there was no hysteria whatsoever. By Monday the delivery option just magically disappeared from every major grocery store’s website.
coerdelion:
You can make your own masks- there are plenty of tutorials on youtube for those with or without sewing machines. It’s easy … but a bit fiddly.
That and clothing brands started selling washable masks. They get a bad rep for being useless but one of my Canadian clients is currently sewing cloth masks for the nurses, and according to the nurses “it does 30% of the job, we’ll take what we can get”.

reply_text:
honeyhiphop:
article saying the reason why we low in supplies, or out is because china bought it all and got it shiipped into there country
Don’t believe everything you read. That article sounds just as a click bait and not like a reliable source. I wouldn’t google to prove if it’s right or wrong but I will give you a couple of question for some critical thinking:
All countries has contracts set up in place on the amount of export and import. Usually they have few chains of suppliers coming from different countries to sustain flow of products in case if there is a political/economical problem with one of the suppliers. That means that they need to honor their deals and they can not just say that let’s say Australia wouldn’t get their groceries (or whatever else) just because China decided to buy it. Everyone has contractual obligations.
However supply chains are indeed suffering right now because this products have never been in such a demand and there was a certain amount of stock produced. When everything suddenly got sold out it still takes tome to produce it. And now it’s not only to produce it but also increase the capacity of your factories to produce higher amount of stock. Which takes time. And we are in the situation where a lot of factories have been stopped not even talking about increasing their production.
I’m sure China is buying a lot but they are also sending a lot of help including physical goods to other countries that need more help.
So I totally wouldn’t take seriously that article. Or I would’ve done the research to confirm that info.

reply_text:
makeyourlogoo:
Is Corona Virus Pandemic really directly or indirectly affecting Orders?
There are many reasons why your sales levels could rise or fall. Let’s not get into the habit of conveniently blaming the Covid pandemic for everything. I’ve been seeing a lot of sellers doing this lately. Perhaps your competitors are doing a better job winning over your potential clients. Maybe there just isn’t as much demand for your services, or perhaps your service offering has grown a bit stale, and needs to be updated. Maybe your gig has entered rotation in the search results, and isn’t being seen by as many people as before. Are you doing any self-marketing? Are you doing anything on your own to connect to your target customers?
If things aren’t going as well as they once were, perhaps there are things that YOU can do to turn things back around. Trying to find something else to blame for the low sales isn’t a productive way to improve your success.

thread_text:
Hi there,
Greetings! Hope you all are well. I’m here since 2017. Day by day the performance is going well.
But is this year a caution for me? Why?
Because I’m an eCommerce product photo editor and image background remover. Most of my clothing brand buyers are importing their dress product from China((COVID-19))! Nowadays I think they are in very complex condition. Maybe that’s why the number of new buyer is decreasing! and I’m getting less product photos. Though other photo types are going well.
What’s about your Fiverr category/sector? Is everything going well? Write in comment/reply box.
Thanks & Regards,
reply_text:
I manage a German translation team Gig and also wondered the same thing.
However, I myself haven’t seen a decrease in the last few days. Our impressions, sales, new buyers and gig ranking are actually significantly increasing currently even though many of our orders are user manuals for new products (usually from China).
But I’m really interested about how other categories are doing too…

I was just reading that most who get it only have mild flu like symptoms. They do not know why some people die from it but it seems to be an over reaction of some people’s immune systems in response to the virus. People who work in hospitals, and the elderly or those with less robust immune systems seem to come down with it the worst, although top officials in some countries have also come down with it.
So far in the U.S. there have been 60 confirmed cases in just a few states. Unfortunately people returning from the eastern countries who were exposed to the virus on planes have boarded planes to various destinations around the country. So far the government response has been much less than ideal.

Corona virus kills a lot less than that, and not everyone who gets it dies from it.

Some people who are exposed to it have their immune systems over react to it which then send too many attack cells into the lungs. The die off of cells in the lungs chokes off the oxygen supply.
It is spread when people sneeze or cough. It may also be spread from touching things with droplets on it. Wash hands after touching things in public for 20 seconds at least or use hand sanitizer and do not touch your face eyes or mouth.

It is affecting and will be affecting a lot of businesses and areas. Already a lot of markets are affected including oil and gas and even manufacturing and phones, TV etc potentially might have higher prices in the next year or so. The impacts are going to be way dipper and extend and after the virus epidemia is done.
I live in one of the countries with highest numbers of sick people but this government handled situation amazingly fast and doing everything to stop the spread. They found all contacts of sick people (which are more than 2000 people that they found and quarantined as a prevention even without symptoms), closed borders (which a lot of people doesn’t like), made it a CRIMINAL offence to withhold information about your whereabouts and your health condition. Your visas will be revoked and you will be deported from the country if you breached home quarantine. Government will pay all your medical bills if you get sick and if you are in official quarantine you will be compensated 100$ for each day.
But there is no point to panic because of this and just to take normal precautions which should’ve been common sense by now, not to sneeze and cough with open mouth, do not spit on the streets, wash your hands and don’t touch your face. Seriously it’s all common sense and governments shouldn’t be telling us to follow this rules.
We still have more chances to be hit by a car.
But industries will be affected in short and long run.

thread_text:
Hi there,

But is this year a caution for me? Why?
Because I’m an eCommerce product photo editor and image background remover. Most of my clothing brand buyers are importing their dress product from China((COVID-19))! Nowadays I think they are in very complex condition. Maybe that’s why the number of new buyer is decreasing! and I’m getting less product photos. Though other photo types are going well.

reply_text:
Auto manufacturing has been almost halted in many countries including China and Korea. It’s having a worldwide economic impact. People can spread the disease even before they know they are sick. Also the ones who spread it can have a mild version of it while spreading it to people who will have over reactions to it and possibly die from it. Places like schools, hospitals and jails and prisons are particularly going to be breeding grounds.
As freelancers it’s possible to stay home and not go to places in public right now until we see how much of our area is going to be affected. So if this gets out of control at least many of us don’t have offices to go to.

reply_text:
mariashtelle1:
The mask wouldn’t save you anyway
Not entirely correct. Depending on the mask. An N95 disposable mask (or P2 / P3 for European equivilant) do offer a form of protection, but health officials are cautious to recommend them because most people won’t use them properly (fitted flush to the face properly at each use) and they’re not designed for more than short term use. They’re also a little expensive.
A regular surgical mask does give some degree but the main reason is that is helps protect people when touching their face/mouth (which they do some 23-40 times an hour) - Wearing a mask reduces the risk of transmission, if nominally, as long as you’re practicing good hand hygeine as well.
As you rightly said, The other benefit is that they also help reduce a person who is infected spreading it further theoretically.
I’m a bit screwed either way as I have a big beard Time to head to the bunker!!

I think it is a disguise/excuse for an already tanking economy. However, I am looking forward to see how people here on Malta react.
There is a building site in my town where they illegally carry on working through the night with no lights on (8 floors up). No one wears hard hats and there has already been one death. Then a few days ago the owner came to hand out white masks to protect the workers from the dreaded Corono virus.
The world is just mad.

Hi there,

reply_text:
Both of my cats have feline coronavirus. After 2 years of dealing with it, it’s so strange to hear “coronavirus” in human context. News headlines are so confusing to me right now.
Other animals (dogs, foxes, etc.) have it but it’s incurable and 100% fatal past a certain stage for cats only. Vaccines have been in the works for over a decade but nothing conclusively positive has come out of it yet.

Coronavirus in cats triggers liquid forming in either lungs or stomach (the latter would be the more “popular” scenario) as the final stage. It’s around 5% of cases, the rest are non-fatal. It’d be pretty visible if that was the case.
Sneezing might be the symptom of another 1000 viruses cats gets so easily. These two I got are the first pets I got as an adult and I’m honestly scandalized by the sheer number of things that might go wrong with a cat.

lenasemenkova:
Coronavirus in cats triggers liquid forming in either lungs or stomach
Yes same for humans. The liquid in humans forms in the lungs from inflammation. That’s what causes death, from the immune system going wild and so much inflammation in the lungs producing fluid. The people who survive have immune systems that knock out the virus before it gets to that stage.

Huh, similar indeed. It mostly kills very young kittens and elderly cats. Mine are 5 years old and I get them immunostimulant treatment once a year, that’s all that can be done.
It’s interesting that it’s curable in dogs but incurable in cats but science hasn’t figured out why yet. Reading research on this is the most frustrating thing. A lot of "we don’t know"s in there.

reply_text: I found out that when cats get something they don’t usually get rid of it. Some can live with a disease for a while. I had a cat with feline HIV. That was bad. I had to have him put down. My last cat developed hyperthyroidism which is fatal in cats. I learned that when cats stop eating it is most humane to have them put to sleep. It seems to be the symptom that indicates it’s the end of life for them.

reply_text:
It spreads very easily and quickly and kills 2 to 3% of those who get it, unlike the flu with only kills .1%. No cures for a virus. This is something unlike anything before it. Things have changed. Hopefully a vaccine will come along for it soon.
Expect to see people wearing masks in public, restaurants closing and who knows what else, on a permanent basis. We all are fortunate who work from home.
Notice that a cruise ship was a place where many caught it. Being in an enclosed area with others is to be avoided if possible. Public transport for example might see a decline. Starbucks stock may take a hit for example. Think of any place where you are around lots of other people.
And apparently people can have it without symptoms and give it to others. How much will people’s way of life be changed?
It’s hard to think of any industry not affected potentially. Home renting and buying? Staying in hotels? Did the last residents have it? What about washing your clothing at a laundromat? Going to a library? Fast food restaurants including drive thru’s?

michal247:
Do we have any information about what caused COVID-19?
misscrystal:
Yes eating bats in a certain Asian country. Apparently they have the virus and it was able to transfer to people.
Bats are one theory, and not an overly realistic one, if you’re following the details of current events (as well as the constantly-changing propaganda coming out of a certain Asian country). Other people seem to present a rather strong case for a more intentional source of the virus – developed in a lab (in the same city the virus was first reported in), and accidentally released into the population.
The fact that the certain Asian country is now trying to blame the USA military as the source of the virus also tends to lend support for the second source story – the laboratory source.
Until that certain Asian nation actually releases factual data, however, no one will know for certain where, and how the virus actually got its start.

fastcopywriter:
I bet that cancellation will hurt your order completion rate.
My stats are all 100% but then there are all kinds of invisible metrics we don’t know about.
The entire situation opens endless possibilities for buyers to demand refunds over actual or pretend event cancellations, though. But this is something I’d rather not think about.
If I get any more orders for event promos, I’ll probably be putting together a short disclaimer to please keep checking if an event is still a go and that no refund will be possible if the event is canceled after the delivery. Then watch me get reported for being greedy and heartless in the face of a pandemic
Revenue-wise, I’m one order away from 50% of my monthly income but my inbox is completely dead since Thursday (minus a few orders that were previously agreed upon). If the trend continues, I’ll probably have to revamp the gig in some way to make it clearer than I don’t only do print event promos.

reply_text:
Throwing in my two cents: Correlation ≠ causation. It’s not the virus itself, it’s the the consequences of fear caused by the virus.
This actually boosts certain types of industries, such as suppliers of emergency goods, while it affects others negatively because consumers are diverting their available funds to those goods, from things of lesser relative importance.
One of my favorite quotes:
Just because you see a turkey flying in a tornado doesn’t mean turkeys can fly.
In other words: just because you’re doing well when there’s a good economy, doesn’t mean you’ll keep doing well if what you offer isn’t a critical-to-survival good/service. I’ll admit I’m exaggerating, but the point stands; people are going to prioritize. This was witnessed during the American Great Depression, and is witnessed any time a noticeable recession occurs in any established economy. Nowadays, being global and digital only means the effects are even more noticed by those who rely on being a global economy like many on Fiverr.
Those who don’t know history are doomed to repeat it.
Many people seem confused by this event, but it’s not a new phenomena. (Remember the H1N1?) Yes, there will be victims (the flu still has more deaths-per-year, thus far). Yes, this is something to be attentive to (though you’d have to be rather socially-starved to be completely out-of-the-loop). Yes, it’s cause to take a few extra steps to be a bit more safe (if an individual isn’t already practicing good hygiene). But this IS. NOT. NEW.
The cancellation of events are for the sake of protecting people from themselves, because people will rationalize that going to a massive gathering is more important than their health AND the health of the people around them. (Like some people rationalize that answering a text is more important than focusing on the road. It doesn’t matter how often ‘nothing’ happens, it only takes one time for disaster to occur.)
I should probably get off the soapbox, though. Not sure how I ended up on it, actually. I was only going to make a short comment.

For the U.S. we haven’t the resources needed. The hospitals were already stretched to their limits at maximum capacity. Food banks, cuts in social services, cuts in Medicare, we have no reserves or planning whatsoever. We’ve only tested a few hundred people for the virus. Test kits are in very short supply. People could only be tested if they had a high fever and cough.
Our main hope is that the virus isn’t as active when the weather warms up in the spring. I’m not sure if we’ve ever had nationwide martial law of not but suddenly anything seems possible.

Scam alert
Inserting a scam warning of a different kind than the ones we usually get here - there are already people trying to take advantage of the situation by sending emails, pretending to be from a country’s main health organization and asking to open an attachment with questions related to COVID-19 which then will install malware on the computer to grab passwords and such. Take care of yourselves, everyone, in many ways, washing your hands doesn’t help against everything
More on topic, I’m still getting orders for the moment, including from Chinese customers.

Because I’m an eCommerce product photo editor and image background remover. Most of my clothing brand buyers are importing their dress product from China((COVID-19))! Nowadays I think they are in very complex condition. Maybe that’s why the number of new buyer is decreasing! and I’m getting less product photos. Though other photo types are going well.
What’s about your Fiverr category/sector? Is everything going well? Write in comment/reply box.
Thanks & Regards,
reply_text:
I don’t have a lot of faith in disclaimers, they can cause two things.
People don’t order because they don’t like the disclaimer
People order and ignore the disclaimers
You can set up your gig for 0 revisions, and people can still request revisions.
Fiverr puts too much pressure on the sellers. We’re supposed to deliver perfect work, 100% of the time. If the client is not happy, we’re supposed to work with the client until happiness is achieved. It’s all subjective, and we’re not protected.
On Uber, if you show up to a location and the passenger doesn’t show up, you can cancel and collect $3.90. If you pick up the passenger and deliver him, you’re gonna get paid even if he gives you 1 star. You can also get your money right away if you don’t mind paying a 50 cent fee. Or send it to Uber’s debit card without the fee.
I think for Fiverr to get better, they need to learn from Uber and other companies.

Personally, I think it’s much more normal that this topic exists at this time than all the “got my level 1 badge” threads, for example, which I find somewhat surreal.
There are people here who need their Fiverr earnings to buy food for themselves and their family, to pay their health insurance, rent and other necessities, and of course, they are worried now, especially if they see a drop in their orders and want to find out if everyone isn’t getting orders anymore either, what they do or plan to do if it is so and continues, and so on.
This is the conversations category, if you hover it in the category lists, you’ll find that it says that it’s a catch-all for any discussions that don’t fit anywhere else and for non-Fiverr related discussions and “anything else that doesn’t break the forum rules or other community guidelines”.

reply_text:
It’s definitely affecting the orders. Whenever something disrupts the global and regional markets, and there are closures, there is bound to be a decline. Keep in mind, many work has totally suspended or got cancelled, so demand is obviously going to get lower as well. Just because people are locked up inside their homes doesn’t mean they’ll order more online.
People actually need to go to work and have projects in order to give us work so this will definitely affect us freelancers and it might get worse as more strict protocols and longer shutdowns are in place.
The only silver lining is the hope that the virus might be redundant or less effective as the weather gets warmer. It’s not a myth, I’ve been reading up and there’s actual evidence that heat makes it less potent if not totally obscure.

reply_text:
nikavoice:
I’m curious how much money (per mile) do Uber/Lyft drivers make today? I use to keep up with a few drivers on YT but it’s been a longtime.
What Uber pays per mile depends on where you are in the USA or in the world. In South Florida, we get $0.62 per mile, $0.12 per minute. I think taxi drivers make $1.25 per mile, $0.25 per minute. Uber drivers make more when they drive luxury vehicles, huge minivans, etc. If there are no surges (extra money for increased demand), I will filter towards long rides, and reject short rides (as long as Uber lets me, they can disable that function if you reject too many rides). If there is a surge, I will drive towards it (if it’s close) and go online and accept the first ride I get.
A fellow driver tells me his goal is making $100 in 5 hours. Sometimes that’s possible, other time it’s not. On average, I make $12 to $15 an hour. It’s a job that requires patience because the first hour might be horrible, but on the next hour you might get great surges.

Yes, actually heat and warm weather affects human immune system in a positive way, because it should improve blood circulation and help fight viruses. There’s the possibility that summer also lifts people’s melatonin and vitamin D levels, which can boost their immune systems, and that viruses lose their punch in warmer weather because their fatty coating degrades.
Fingers crossed.

reply_text:
I have two orders so far directly linked to the virus, informational documents.
The economy as a whole of course takes a massive hit but people still spend money, just not as much and partly on different things, and more on certain things.
There will be demand for new things/services or more of some already existing things/services, while the world tries to adapt and keep functioning.
Whether someone has work or not, now highly depends on what exactly one does, and if there are alternatives. Here , for example, people who work in restaurants which are empty or closed, are being suggested they could work in farming, as the workers from abroad will be missing, when borders are and stay closed for a while. Money might, also in the long run, in the face of this experience, be diverted to training more health workers, etc.

Sure, but a massive influx of new and inexperienced sellers might work in the favor of those high rated sellers with hundreds of reviews, purely because to a buyer the alternative will seem so far behind. The main threat could be sluggish economic movement which will force businesses to advertise less, delay launches and slow down production.
The next 3-4 months may be slower, followed by a huge resurgence. It is probably a good time for most freelancers to sharpen their swords and work on newer, more polished offerings to capitalize when the market eventually bottoms out.

reply_text:
fastcopywriter:
In South Florida, we get $0.62 per mile, $0.12 per minute. I think taxi drivers make $1.25 per mile, $0.25 per minute.
SoFlo is a huge market, I know there are areas like Fort. Lauderdale/Hollywood, Hallandale, Palm Beach, and Miami is a beast of it’s own. I used to go to the Opa Locka/Hialeah Flea Market, phew that was fun.
fastcopywriter:
A fellow driver tells me his goal is making $100 in 5 hours. Sometimes that’s possible, other time it’s not. On average, I make $12 to $15 an hour. It’s a job that requires patience because the first hour might be horrible, but on the next hour you might get great surges.
$12-$15 is not too shabby. I’m happy you found something that gives you extra income, it’s an honest and decent wage. As a driver how are you handling the virus with passengers and such? I’m sure business will pick up more considering the situation.

reply_text:
What people don’t understand, is that the prices paid now in terms of the economy make public health worse long-term.
One minute it’s cool and normal to stockpile sanitizer and toilet paper and close all businesses because of a virus that has negligible effects on 80% of people. However, no one understands that you can only do that once while the economy is as it is. Should a more serious health crisis follow this one, (which diseases do in periods of economic decline) you’re pretty much done for.
Sadly, we don’t live in a world of logical long-think. We live in a media and social media world of instant OMG! Coupled with a bit of “I’m an expert” because I follow the news.
Don’t waste your energy arguing, though, you’ll never be allowed to have a logical discussion in times like these. You’ll just be flagged as some kind of human monster because you are not going “OMG!” yourself.

What people don’t understand, is that the prices paid now in terms of the economy make public health worse long-term.
One minute it’s cool and normal to stockpile sanitizer and toilet paper and close all businesses because of a virus that has negligible effects on 80% of people. After the 2008 financial crisis, this happened in Greece with massive self-death increases (can’t say the S word), and spikes in bygone diseases like Malaria:
Malaria has returned to Greece as financial cuts contribute to the re-emergence of a once extinct disease. … Other mosquito-borne diseases that have slipped back into Greece include West Nile virus. Statistics show that there were 70 instances of mosquito borne diseases in Greece in the first nine months of the year.
Source 1
No money, no future economy, no public health.

The pure growth in reaction to this shows the collective anxiety we all have. No one knows the true answers because we have not faced a pandemic like this in our lifetimes. It is hard to see the true ripple effect until well after the recovery from this. Public and personal health will take priority over business right now. Accepting that is important to making it through this.
One of my Gigs was featured as an editor’s pick to be on the front page of Fiverr. My immediate thought was, “This is wonderful, but terrible timing because I think this is not a normal operating cycle with such a pandemic and Fiverr, will receive less exposure.”
I also thought Bernie Sanders would be the next US president. So, what do I know, really?

Greetings! Hope you all are well. I’m here since 2017. Day by day the performance is going well.
But is this year a caution for me? Why?
Because I’m an eCommerce product photo editor and image background remover. Most of my clothing brand buyers are importing their dress product from China((COVID-19))! Nowadays I think they are in very complex condition. Maybe that’s why the number of new buyer is decreasing! and I’m getting less product photos. Though other photo types are going well.
What’s about your Fiverr category/sector? Is everything going well? Write in comment/reply box.
Thanks & Regards,
reply_text:
perfectionistop:
Check out the regulations that you actually have there. Price regulations, monopolies, concessions, licences, subsides. it’s not free at all.
I know. I live here.

reply_text:
misscrystal:
We do not have “public health care” here, or anything close to it. We have public “who cares?”
Yup! I’m one of the few who is covered on all fronts, Medical, Dental, and Vision. Other people not so much. It’s definitely not cheap. ACA is available as well as Medicare/Medicaid. There are a group of people who simply cannot afford to pay these high premiums.
Sorry to hear about your breathing issue. How are you feeling today?

reply_text:
nikavoice:
As a driver how are you handling the virus with passengers and such?
My father doesn’t want me to drive, so I’m going to respect his wishes. One thing I’ve learned is that you can have corona virus, not know it, and be spreading it around.
As for business, I think it’s going down. A lot of people are staying home, festivals are being cancelled, so demand has gone down.
I imagine demand on Fiverr should increase. A friend of mine works at a bank, and he’s working from home thanks to covid. School is being cancelled as well, lots of kids are getting homework. Will they be hiring proofreaders? Who knows?

I got to design a few hand sanitize labels yesterday night & day before… So far not soo bad for me… but I guess orders will be less by Friday…
In Sri Lanka government has given holidays till Friday… I live very close to a major town and since yesterday I didn’t even hear much vehicle noises… at times it feels sooo creepy & too gloomy, like in horror movies… The good side of holidays is I get to hear birds singing & bees buzzing…

reply_text:
saaad47:
I’m 23 and I am Quarantining. It’s not an over reaction.
People your age are unlikely to catch covid. Also, most people aren’t self-isolating, Home Depot and local supermarkets have been as busy as ever. In fact, I think some folks are using this opportunity to work on construction projects, gardening, etc.
blavaro:
Furthermore self-quarantine is mainly supposed to stop spreading the infection.
We’ll see if it works. I know kids on Spring Break have been going to the beach even though the governor of Florida closed the beaches. How do you enforce that? Do you put a cop on every beach? It’s very impractical. In California, they expect people to snitch on lawbreakers, good luck with that. Most people mind their own business unless a crime is commited against them.
Besides, how long do you think people can live like this? Who wants to live a life without restaurants, movie theaters, etc? Who wants to cook every meal at home and overpay for toilet paper on eBay?
People talk about the sacrifices civilians made during WW2, but that was different, and those civilians still had access to movies and other entertainments. It was gas that was rationed, people grew victory gardens, and lived with a lot less. Ironically, there was still a black market, people selling counterfeit gas cards, etc.
Now things are pretty crazy. I read that in New Jersey a family got arrested for inviting more than 50 people to a wedding at home.
On the other hand, in Philadelphia they are delaying arrests of those who “commit certain non-violent offenses.” So if someone wants to burglarize homes in Philly, this is the perfect time to do it.
“Due to the confirmed case of #COVID19 from community spread, Salt Lake City Police Department is asking all criminal activities/nefarious behavior to cease until further notice,” the Utah capital’s law enforcement wrote in a tweet. “We appreciate your anticipated cooperation in halting crime & thank criminals in advance.”
Why not wish for rainbows and lollypops?

reply_text:
It’s a new disease which all of us will come into contact with. It’s realistic to think we all will get it. One in five of us will need to be hospitalized. We do not have that kind of capacity in our hospitals.
One fifth of our entire country may need to be hospitalized.
fastcopywriter:
Is it fair to shut down society for the one fifth that are in danger?
It sounds like you can’t grasp the gravity of the situation.
No one has immunity to this disease and it’s impossible to determine who will be able to throw it off like a case of the flu, and who will become more sick.
We now have a U.S. senator who tested positive, and a governor as I recall. Look at what happened to Italy. We unfortunately can expect that here, no reason to believe otherwise. By shutting things down we might be able to “flatten the curve” meaning not have as high a spike before cases start to go down. It’s our best hope.
So far we are a long way from the time when cases will start to go down. I wish everyone could realize the importance of at least keeping a distance between themselves and others, and frequent hand washing.
It’s not just about each of us trying to not get sick. It’s about having it without any symptoms, and going around where others are and spreading it to them. So even if you don’t have symptoms you may put others into danger by coming into close proximity to them. This is a common way people get it.
I want to offer a bit of hope as well as this gloomy report:
There is a new drug called remdesivir in testing that so far shows it can actually cure people of corona virus. It is undergoing clinical trials in three places in the US in 1000 patients.
First results are expected in late April.

Yes, in my opinion. Human life and health has no price. Economy will take a hit, eventually recover, but some people that catch this virus will unfortunately not share the same fate.
And yet Italy is denying respirators to people over 60. See? Human life has a price, and when the government controls your healthcare, they decide who lives and who dies, who’s valuable and who has been alive too long for them to care.
misscrystal:
No one has immunity to this disease and it’s impossible to determine who will be able to throw it off like a case of the flu, and who will become more sick.
My point is not everyone is susceptible to this disease, not everyone catches it. Right now Home Depot (and other retailers I assume) instituted a rule where the store can’t have more than 100 people inside, including employees. So you can imagine the long lines of people waiting to get in. Ironically, there’s not much social isolation when you’re standing in line, so the measures are futile.
I do hope remdesivir works, I can’t wait to go back to normal. I hope we never again shut down society over a disease.
blavaro:
It is pity that in our country people still think so selfish these days.
Selfishness is the natural state of people. Altruism and self-sacrifice are aberrations. When someone orders for me, it’s for selfish reasons, same reason I serve my customers well. Altruism would require me to refund every order and tell my client, “I love you so much, that I want to work for you for free.” That I’ll never do, I might give my clients extras to keep him coming back, see? Selfish reasons, but I wont’ sacrifice my time and my money for anyone. If anyone gets a refund, that person is blocked and reported to Fiverr.
catwriter:
But the other day in the supermarket, a woman who was dutifully wearing a mask tried to stand so close behind me she was practically breathing down my neck (and no, it wasn’t for the lack of space, there was plenty of room behind her).

That’s not right. That’s like waiting two years for a kidney, undergoing dialysis three times a week, and when a kidney is finally available, they give it to a celebrity.
If I show up to the hospital first, I’m supposed to be treated first. What kind of sickos choose who gets to live and who gets to die? If someone dies because all respirators were taken, that’s sad, but at least that person didn’t die because someone deemed him or her unworthy.
Older people are worthy. They have families, they’ve paid taxes their entire lives, some of them fought in WW2, they should be honored instead of being sentenced to death by giving that respirator to another patient.
Anyway, that’s my opinion, we can agree to disagree.

fastcopywriter:
Companies should embrace remote work permanently.
When they do that, they might as well embrace hiring freelancers instead of employees. Then it will become a case of companies constantly looking to reduce wage bills by hiring offshore workers.
Then there is the cybersecurity side of things. Then there is the slight problem that when you work from home you degenerate into an overweight blob that lives in less and less underwear every day and panics every time the doorbell rings…
Personally, I’ve regretted freelancing for quite a few years now, as I miss the sociability side of things. However, I did tell everyone who thought I was mad when I left my last company, that within 5-years the economy would collapse and they would all be on benefits… And although I was 3-years off, that has now happened…

reply_text:
This initial post was put up on Feb 27th. At that point, no one knew how this would fully play out in the US where I live. Nor did we really know how it would affect the rest of the world or Gig economy workers. Sitting here on March 25th, Sh&T got real! More than 1/3 of the US population is under stay at home orders. It does not mean that everyone is listening. NY is the epicenter of this in the US for now, cases and deaths are rising at record rates each day countrywide - but mainly NY. A sign of things to come in other states is what many seem to wonder. We are still, although better at testing, need more tests to get a read on the entire picture and testing is backlogged, so I do not believe we have the full picture of how this is spreading in places outside of the major epicenters here.
The daily briefings by Governers, especially Cuomo of NY, and that of our commander in Chief are fascinating and taking the place of sporting events I would be watching for entertainment. I will leave that alone for now.
Good news for self-employed Gig workers who are affected by this. Sounds. like they can file for unemployment and get that plus some via this new bailout bill from congress.
The school system I work in just announced closure for 4 more weeks with remote learning. It should be interesting to see how they implement that.
Amazing how things change in just one short month. It went from we are scared and watching and maybe it won’t be so bad to oh Sh&t!
Stay safe

reply_text:
@silberma1976
Thanks for the heads up on gig worker unemployment benefits:
Gig workers, freelancers, self-employed are eligible
In an unprecedented move, the stimulus bill expands unemployment protections to gig workers, freelancers and self-employed individuals, who typically don’t qualify for unemployment benefits.
Seth Harris, former Deputy U.S. Secretary of Labor, describes this aspect of the stimulus package as a “gigantic change,” but notes that it could be complicated to execute.
“It will be harder [to calculate] because these workers don’t have a W-2 or an average weekly wage,” Harris says. “These folks have income that varies dramatically from week to week or month to month.”
It’s not clear yet how state benefits will be calculated for these workers (from forbes)

misscrystal:
Wow, glad he’s getting better. I wonder if he would have been better on his own. Did he have breathing problems? Did you have contact with him?
Only once three or four weeks ago, I lost track of time since the quarantine began. I don’t think he would have gotten better on his own, the reason he’s in the hospital is because his fever and breathing got a lot worse, and he was feeling really bad. He’s 67, so he’s definitely part of the main demographic for corona.
I’m honestly more concerned about my job. Every time I go to the break room, I’m sitting in places that might have corona. If I push a supermarket cart, that might have corona. I do wear gloves, but what if the inside of the gloves already have corona? This virus is so evil, the way it can lasts for hours on a surface.

My sales/impressions/clicks on my gigs have practically dropped to 0 for about a month now.
You can check my post here
From First Page To Invisibility
Your Fiverr Experience
Hello there Fiverr Community, I wanted to mention some issues that I have encountered and basically see if anyone else has had a similar experience. About a month ago, my gigs went from being on the first page ( for all keywords of interest ) to complete invisibility . My gigs are nowhere to be found, and impressions/clicks have dropped massively ( near zero ). Of course, this has resulted in 0 orders from new clients during the past 30 days ( thankfully I do have some loyal clients working wi…
I am sure other people have the same issues. It should be covid-19 related, but not sure it entirely depends on that.
We are in for a bumpy ride fellas

thread_text:
I’m currently the only person I know in my family or friends group that has covid-19 symptoms. UK testing is pretty much non-existent unless you’re in hospital, but I’m 100% sure I have it. Sudden onset persistent, dry cough with pre-flu symptoms? Never experienced that in my life. Would be a mighty coincidence if it’s anything else.
I’m worried for the elderly and high-risk folks in my community, but for myself this has mostly just been a surreal experience more than anything else. I only leave my flat to go for a walk around the block and I keep well away from other people. I’m indoors for 99% of the day. I read the news obsessively to see the status of my home state, where my family still lives. I’ve deep cleaned my flat and watched almost every episode of cold case files.
Thank god we got a nintendo switch as a wedding gift last year and I have a couple jigsaw puzzles arriving in the post soon.
I also have massive long-term projects on the go at the moment with two beloved clients, so I’m actually living the dream right now work-wise (knock on wood) as I’ve had to take two weeks off of my day job working with kids, so I know have 14 uninterrupted days of VO work.
Anyway how y’all holding up? Anybody else sick? XOX
reply_text: Hello, do you know if you have a temperature? Headache? Body aches? Fatigue? Have you called a doctor or hospital?

reply_text:
Hope it’s not COVID-19, and something else entirely. Here’s hoping, either way, that you get to feeling better soon.
I myself had every intention of going to the gym today but the more the day dragged on, the less I felt up to it. In fact, my sinuses are driving me nuts and my eyes are itchy. I’m pretty sure my allergies are starting to flare up. I’m not really self-isolating but really just staying to myself. Luckily, I can really rest because I have no work to speak of anymore. I had a large order come in yesterday and it’s already done and sent off to the client.
For now, the rest of the day is mine. Thanks to this virus, the school shut down for a week before spring break (by orders of the governor). I had to go in for a short time to get billing done, but other than that, the day is my own
Thinking it’s time to clear off my table and do some puzzles myself. I bought myself a puzzle at Christmas and I guess I can start working on it. My son and my son’s friend who lives with us both did their AMI packets for today. So now, they’re just goofing off. With a dreary day like today, I just want to rest more than I do anything else.
Get well!

I’m absolutely terrified of being sick with anything, so this whole thing has really just made my anxiety skyrocket. I also live with 11 people, which is more than the U.S. President has said to even gather with; what makes matters worse is the two most high risk people in my house (Dad w/ diabetes and Grandma who’s 74) are both refusing to practice social distancing and still going shopping and not washing their hands (incensed beyond belief at that).
I’ve also been doing a lot more church work since we’ve been doing online church. Pumping out social media posts, videoing children’s church lessons, and writing Bible devotions have been my days outside of the three hours I reserve for my writing orders (thankfully, business is still going strong).
I hope you feel better,
@gwyneth_galvin
. Does being sick affect your ability to do VO work at all?

misscrystal:
do you know if you have a temperature? Headache? Body aches?
Nah. I feel like you feel just before you get flu. Sorta achey, not quite right. But I’m 27, and people in my age group by and large present extremely mild symptoms or no symptoms at all.
misscrystal:
Have you called a doctor or hospital?
No, and I don’t plan to. The NHS may collapse under the weight of this crisis in the coming weeks, and I’m not going to contribute to that strain. I am perfectly happy to follow the NHS guidelines and stay home and not make contact with anyone outside of my household. I’m a rule follower

I only leave my flat to go for a walk around the block and I keep well away from other people. I’m indoors for 99% of the day. I read the news obsessively to see the status of my home state, where my family still lives. I’ve deep cleaned my flat and watched almost every episode of cold case files.
Thank god we got a nintendo switch as a wedding gift last year and I have a couple jigsaw puzzles arriving in the post soon.
I also have massive long-term projects on the go at the moment with two beloved clients, so I’m actually living the dream right now work-wise (knock on wood) as I’ve had to take two weeks off of my day job working with kids, so I know have 14 uninterrupted days of VO work.
Anyway how y’all holding up? Anybody else sick? XOX
reply_text:
misscrystal:
I was watching an elderly couple’s video on youtube
I watch their vlog as well! They’re so sweet and apparently close to being fully recovered. It’s a bit encouraging. My dad is 82 and we can’t stop him from going to work.

Thank god we got a nintendo switch as a wedding gift last year and I have a couple jigsaw puzzles arriving in the post soon.
I also have massive long-term projects on the go at the moment with two beloved clients, so I’m actually living the dream right now work-wise (knock on wood) as I’ve had to take two weeks off of my day job working with kids, so I know have 14 uninterrupted days of VO work.
Anyway how y’all holding up? Anybody else sick? XOX

reply_text:
Ah,
@gwyneth_galvin
- sorry to hear this. But glad - in a kinda sardonic way - you’re getting it out of the way early.
My son has it and is self isolating - #2 daughter and I took him a care package of loo roll, washing up liquid, soap and various other bits and pieces, as well as dinner in a vacuum flask thingy tonight. We’ll probably be doing that a lot over the coming fortnight.
Here in Glasgow you cannot get paper goods for love nor money. Soap is in very short supply … but not shampoo for some reason. Shelves and shelves of shampoo and conditioner with no one interested in it. At a pinch, you can use that as shower gel and washing up liquid - it all has the same base, apparently.
Luckily, we’d put some stuff aside for Brexit, which we still have … or at least what’s left of it after Brexit didn’t really happen that much.
And yes, that EFT tapping for increasing lung capacity is a great idea. EFT for anything is a good idea. I have a tapping round for making sure your system is open to accepting everything you do for yourself, which is really useful.
@graphtersawyer
- take a breath, make sure you focus on what you can control rather than the things you can’t … and, if necessary, isolate yourself in your own room as much as possible. Thinking of you.
@creativetie
- take good care of yourself. Not easy to be alone and sick.
I like that we are all here for each other in this community.
Love you all!

reply_text:
Here are symptoms:
People may experience:
Runny nose
Sore throat
Cough
Fever
Pneumonia (which means a lung inflammation)
Difficulty breathing (severe cases)
This is the first I’ve heard of runny nose being a symptom which I’ve had for two weeks. I have never had this before. It’s just today finally getting better. I also had mild chills a few times, and swollen glands in my neck which are now ok.
This list is published by the World Health Organization
I hope it’s ok that I report some facts as I hear them here.
